TEXT: The applicant , born in DATE , is a NORP national and resident in Triel - sur - Seine . He is a technician by profession . In the proceedings before the ORG , he is represented by Me N. Creuzillet , a lawyer practising in GPE .
In DATE the applicant married a NORP national in GPE , and CARDINAL children were born in wedlock in DATE and DATE .

Apparently in DATE , the applicant ’s wife separated from the applicant and returned to GPE with the CARDINAL children . She instituted divorce proceedings with ORG ( ORG ) . Moreover , divorce proceedings were instituted with the GPE tribunal de grande instance . In DATE the Memmingen ORG granted the applicant ’s claim under LAW on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction ( PERSON über die zivilrechtlichen GPE internationaler GPE ) that the children be returned to GPE . Upon appeals lodged by the competent ORG and the applicant ’s wife , his claims was dismissed by ORG ( Zivilsenate ) of ORG ( Oberlandesgericht ) in DATE . In DATE the Memmingen ORG granted the applicant ’s wife custody of the children pending the spouses’ separation . However , in DATE ORG decided that the children should live at the applicant ’s place of residence . In DATE the GPE tribunal de grande instance granted the applicant custody of the children .

In DATE the applicant applied with ORG for a right of access ( ORG ) to his children in DATE and during DATE , as well as a regular access during DATE periods , which he intended to spend with them in GPE . He also requested information about his children . He further applied for an interim injunction .
In these court proceedings , both spouses were represented by counsel .
On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s request for an interim injunction . The defendant had accepted his right to information .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s request for access . The court observed that the applicant wished to spend holidays with his children in GPE , while the defendant , suggesting supervised visits , objected to uncontrolled access . The court considered that , despite his assurances , there was a real risk that the applicant would not return the children at the end of the holidays and thereby create a danger for their well - being . In this respect , the court had regard to the course of the spouses’ separation and divorce proceedings . Having regard to an expert opinion prepared in the context of the custody proceedings , it noted that the children had a very good relationship with their mother and that they were fully integrated at their place of residence . Moreover , given the legal situation in GPE , the applicant ’s assurances that he would return the children at the end of the holidays were not sufficient . In this respect , the court noted that he was not prepared to accept that the children were living with the defendant and that she had custody .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . The court , referring to section DATE of LAW ( Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch ) , confirmed that granting the applicant a right of access including the right to take the children to GPE was - for the time being - contrary to the children ’s well - being . The court noted that the applicant had expressly stated that he did not apply for access to his children in GPE ; and that this matter was not , therefore , at issue in the proceedings .

Under section DATE of LAW , the parent not holding custody is entitled to have access to the child . This right of access may be suspended if such a measure is necessary in the best interest of the child .

In this respect , ORG noted that the children , when questioned by a single judge in DATE , had indicated that they were only prepared to visit the applicant in GPE if accompanied by their mother . They feared to loose the security of their mother ’s presence . According to a psychological expert opinion of DATE , separating the children from their mother entailed a risk for their well - being .

On DATE ORG ( Bundesverfassungsgericht ) refused to entertain the applicant 's constitutional complaint ( ORG ) . ORG considered that the constitutional complaint raised no issue of fundamental importance . In particular , the impugned court decisions did not disclose any discrimination against the applicant , but was reasoned by the risk that the applicant might separate the children from their mother . Moreover , the applicant had not been generally refused a right of access , but only in the concrete circumstances and having regard to the children ’s well - being . The possibility to visit the children in GPE was not excluded . The decision was served upon the applicant ’s counsel on DATE .

Meanwhile , on DATE the GPE tribunal de grande instance , in a default judgment , had granted divorce . It had further decided that both parents had joint custody of the children and that the children should live with their mother . As regards access , it decided that , in case of disagreement between the parents , the applicant had a right of access to the children during all short school holidays and CARDINAL of the summer holidays .
